Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: I was sitting on the edge of my bed, my phone buzzing with a new message from the volunteer coordinator: “All volunteers must report to the center immediately. We need everyone to follow the new safety procedures or we risk being shut down.” My heart pounded. I’d promised to be there, and I knew how much the community depended on our work. But just as I was about to get up, my stepbrother burst into my room, his face pale and eyes red. He’d just gotten the news—his biological father was in the hospital, and things didn’t look good. He collapsed onto the floor, sobbing, and I could feel his pain as if it were my own. I was supposed to be there for him, to support him through this, but the coordinator’s message echoed in my mind. If I didn’t go, I’d be letting down the team and risking the entire service. My stepbrother’s cries grew louder, and I felt torn in two, paralyzed by the weight of both responsibilities pressing down on me.
